posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9645950
Upscaling is almost instant, the problem is that the hardware needs to capture the output from the GBA GPU before the DS GPU which controls the LCDs can display it. This is referenced in hardware documentation.
https://problemkaputt.de/gbatek.htm#dsbackwardscompatiblegbamode
>The GBA screen is centered in the middle of the NDS screen. The surrounding pixels are defined by 32K-color bitmap data in VRAM Block A and B. Each frame, the GBA picture is captured into one block, and is displayed in the next frame (while capturing new data to the other block).
This accounts for the 1 frame of extra input lag.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9645960
So it is related to centring the screen?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646015
It's related to the fact that the GBA GPU does not have direct access to the screen. The DS GPU controls the screen so the GBA output needs to be copied to DS memory and displayed on the next frame.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646019
So 3DS does that to DS and GBA does that with GB too?
Seeing as they both do the same thing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9641813
This makes me wonder. How much lag would some chang DS replacement screen typically have?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646075
That's right.

For the 3DS, the hardware responsible is also documented, and there are open source implementations which use the hardware (libn3ds, open_agb_firm) so you can read how it works in practice.
http://problemkaputt.de/gbatek-3ds-video-lgy-registers-legacy-gba-nds-video-to-framebuffer.htm
>The LGYFB units are for forwarding GBA/NDS/DSi video to 3DS screens with optional scaling. The input comes directly from the GBA/NDS video controller, the output must be DMAed to memory.
Once the DS/GBA video output is copied to 3DS memory the 3DS LCD controller can display it, but this adds one frame of delay.

GB on GBA works in a similar way. The output from the GB is used as a background layer for the GBA GPU. This also means 1 frame of buffering. It also means that the GBA GPU can add effects to the GB video like scaling, rotation, translation and mosaic which this homebrew demonstrates.
https://github.com/Extrems/gba-switch-to-gbc
https://files.catbox.moe/gite3a.gba

GB on 3DS has much more input lag than the others because that's full emulation.

>>9646165
I recall that a handful of PS1 games on PS2 are known to sometimes suffer music playback issues, if you use the PS2's option to shorten loading times.
But that's a side effect of an optional enhancement that has no detriment to a majority of PS1 games played on PS2.

Also as GBA games on NDS goes, it's been well documented by now that there's a major bug in both versions of Mega Man Battle Network 4 where during WoodMan's scenario, it tries to load in non-existent sprite graphic data from an invalid address, that will render the game unplayable for an extended period, and Nintendo had to officially acknowledge the issue.
The bug was in the ROM's program, but the handling in the NDS hardware resulted in gameplay disruption whilst on GBA it was benign.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646182
Is that related to the console or the screen?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646212
It's the console. The NDS only outputs video at 59.83Hz but the GBA outputs video at 59.74Hz. The DS compensates by repeating a frame every few seconds.
Depending on the DS model the screen might be blurry enough for the flicker effect to work, but the speed issue makes it more obvious that it's flicker.

posts.com:
>>9646223

posts.sub: How would YOU fix the sega saturn?
posts.com:
As we all know, sega sharturn was a piece of shart that made sega bleed money, but could it have been designed differently? Here's my take.
>CPU:
1x Hitachi SH-2 @28MHz, maybe just simply grab the 23Mhz one from the 32X because this crap is hindered by 16-bit ISA anyway.
>GPU:
Geometry DSP optimized for maximum flat shaded polygon performance. Get rid of all the other functions and try to reach 1 million flat shaded polygon per second.
A simple VDP that only draws backdrop image and transform sprites vertically and horizontally for use in 2.5D games.
>co-processor:
8 MHz 68000 handling the CD and background music.
>Sound:
Genesis FM sound chip directly connected to hitachi SH-2 to produce sfx.
4 channel PCM sound chip similar to amiga paula to minimize production cost, handled by 68000 chip, intended to stream audio data from the CD or play protracker background music.
>RAM
1.5MB main RAM, 256K framebuffer.
>CD format
0.75x speed (100KB/s) CD drive to let it make use of cheap flimsy parts without breaking down constantly
50MB micro-CD for minimum seek time and cheaper cost.
Copy protection ASIC.
>retail price
$160 bucks
no more than 30 bucks for a game

>performance figure
1 million flat shaded polygons per second, all games ported into this machine will be entirely flat shaded.
120fps games with 84,000 polygons per frame, faster than the PS1 and N64 could ever dream to be.
Ugly but fast and complex games The epitome of fuck what everyone else thinks: the console..

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9632031
There's nothing really "bad" about the Steam Deck. Its the best bang for your buck x86 handheld that there is, the trackpads are a great addition that I sometimes prefer using over the right analog stick for camera movement, and Valve updates Proton enough that games work more than they don't from my experience. Plus when you connect it to a Dock, there's tons of great upscaling options for 2D/3D games with SteamOS compared to Windows by default.
The only real cons are personal nitpicks, like how some games like RE4 don't make full use of the 16:10 display, displaying black bars on the top and bottom like its in widescreen. And while its large and is more comfortable to use than expected, its bulky enough that it isn't exactly "portable" like the Ayaneo Air if that makes any sense. Small hand-handed people may want to wait for their Air Plus model instead. And of course since this is running Linux, not all PC games like say Silent Hill 4 boot from my experience. Still want to stress that its not all unplayable and game compatibility is very good at this point and only growing, but still keep in mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9638357
Just bought some vitas. All on eBay. 2/3 were Japanese used: 1000 and 1100. Had to return the "excellent condition FW 3.18" for being the latest firmware and having severe burn-in from the hot charging port. The other JP one arrived perfectly, exactly as the seller and I personally discussed, and had the correct FW, no mura spots, no burn-in.
It does matter to get a 3.60 or lower firmware, people are lying when they say high FW can easily get CFW.
Ordered a US 1000 Vita to replace the returned 1100.
No interest in the 2000. The IPS is easier to take care of and internal memory card is convenient but offers no good sub pixel arrangement for crispness, no good blacks or contrasts, plus the 1000 OLED has good motion controls.
The OLED must be properly cared for though. You can't overcharge it or max the current to 2A over 5v constantly or you'll get burn-in. And you need a sleep timer or screensaver to prevent mura/splotches from developing, and set the brightness low most of the time for the same reason. It's actually worrying how bright it is at max. Halfway was still pretty bright in light and minimum is highly visible in the dark. So far this Vita looks pretty worth it. I love my PSP and it won't replace it for those games or the superior XMB clicky sounds but Vita is very good at its own thing.
If you're willing to message sellers directly and talk like a human being, you'll get a really sweet deal on an excellent condition Vita and then it's just a matter of taking care of it properly.
One more thing. The JP vitas have a different battery model in them than the US and EU versions. They're all the same true capacity BUT the JPN ones have the top & bottom 20%-iles locked off. For most people, this will help them not wreck their batteries in 3 years. For power users, it could be a concern if you need the freedom. Personally, I recommend not maxing/mining your charge if you get US/EU anyway and just get a large 30,000mAh battery bank you can carry instead.

>>9643123
I have only tried the Gamesir X2 USB Type-C (Bottom row, center column in your picture), but... The most Important things I can remember:

- Buttons and d-pad are on a whole new level compared to the RG351V I own,Provided that you like clicky tactile feedback.

- The short grips don't make it comfortable for twin stick gameplay. If you want to play FPS, get something bigger with grips that extend downwards, like the ones in the top corners. Or a smartphone clip for a ds4 or XB controller.

- It's not a great solution if you are going to use it on the go during short commutes, or if you have to change trains every 15-20 min. With no built-in battery and no off-button it keeps draining the phone's battery all the time, so you will want to disassemble it as soon as your train or bus gets to destination (and you need to be careful to not mess the usb port on the phone, that spring is extra strong).

Nothing of this is a problem if you will use it at home or get to sit on on public transport for 40 minutes without interruptions.

- Think carefully about which model you want, USB-C or Bluetooth. Many Android games don't support USB controllers (Apex Legends, but that one is dead now). I have the Xbox version and it's guaranteed to work with Gamepass, and Retroarch detects it ok, although it may give you some remapping headaches from time to time.

My personal experience:
1) Get the Gamesir X2 because another handheld is overkill and I already have a good quality phone that integer scales GBA perfectly and can do almost every system
2) I spend more time getting the phone in than playing (exagerated)
3) I have a close call while disassembling it (controller ends in the floor of the train while it brakes)
4) Another mishap happens when I can't grip it properly, folds itseld and one analog stick cap goes flying
5) I end getting an RG351v, the Gamesir ends at home. I keep saying I will use it on the couch, but... nope. In love with the 351, playing Pokémon Clover.

>>9627292
Short of MAP09: Stronghold, which is the toughest official map on Nightmare, due to the uninterrupted storm of back and forth lead (being long thought outright impossible, and it was the last official map to be beaten on that difficulty), I'm going to say no. Plutonia overall just plays harder ball overall, ambushes which are deadly already are made magnitudes harder on Nightmare in ways which TNT just can't match in the same way, and the combat is overall just far more intense.
Zombies with guns are a serious menace on Nightmare, but the insidious encounter design inherent to Plutonia just takes it to another level anyway when pumped up like that.

>>9627028
>>9627052
Both TNT Evilution and The Plutonia Experiment feature a dedicated deathmatch only arena in one of their levels. Eviluton's MAP26: Ballistyx, by Mark Snell (with some unclear work by Jim Lowell), features a crude DM arena in a space which is visible in singleplayer, but which you cannot access.

Plutonia's MAP30: Gateway To Hell, by Milo Casali, features a full fledged deathmatch arena completely separated from the singleplayer level, which isn't normally accessible or visible in single player. It seems like a bit of an afterthought though, like it's something Milo drew up while he had some free time and was bored (maybe they were waiting for one of Dario's maps to have its nodes drawn), as the texture alignment is slightly less refined in a couple of places, and there's one or two spots you can get stuck on.
There's probably earlier examples than these, because having a separate deathmatch area seems like a fairly simple conclusion to a single player map not being that great for deathmatch, but these are notable, official ones even.

Wrong and wrong:

The three id artists doing each pixel by hand for everything in the game when other companies were content with compressing stock photos or larger illustrations was probably very time consuming, but it holds up today. What's your workflow like?

posts.name: ViolentRumbleAnon
posts.com:
>>9635925
>What's your workflow like?
Nothing fancy. I just kinda make outlines of different sections over the UV map and try to layer some materials over it until it looks sufficiently 'textured'. Then I'll manually add any needed highlights and shadows... which tends to take me a while on characters or anything else that's organic.
I also have a baked ambient occlusion map that I layer over everything, but on this low-poly of a model that doesn't account for much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9640124
>you cant just cross lines willy nilly
You can cross lines of a sector, as long as they don't occupy the same vertical space as the crossed sector. ("Sector-over-sector" effect, something the Doom engine cannot do)

>trying to build room over room stuff is also the worst
Mapster's TRoR mechanism is quite easy once you get the hang of it. And also, most Doom source ports don't even support RoR.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9641341
>mbf21 already has facsimile of decorate
It really doesn't, DecoHack is a separate tool for writing stuff in a Decorate style way which is then 'compiled' for DeHacked and MBF21 tables. These tables aren't readable by a person, and they're a bitch to add to from the dev side, as well as maintain if they grow bigger.
If people want to add new function calls to whatever Decorate substitute they're cooking up, it's going to be a millions easier and less painful if it doesn't have to work like a 30 year old gross hack.

>>9642695
Not that anon, but if you mean Phantom Fury it's almost certainly on Unreal or Unity given the unfitting post-processing smeared over the trailer footage.
Honestly, one of these big 'boomer shooter' studios actually using a classic engine was a complete fluke and probably won't happen again. Any 90s shooter engine requires you to actually commit to an aesthetic in every aspect of the art rather than just slapping on shaders and changing the lighting, which is what most aspiring game developers are taught to do nowadays.
The best you can hope for is some hyper-autist shitting out a GZDoom game with every chicken man special effect cranked up to max and 'F.E.A.R. AI' plastered on every advertisement because two enemies can yell "OH SHIT FUCKITY ASS SHIT FUCK" at each other after you kill their friend who was stuck walking into a trash can.

posts.com:
When the topic of early 3d gaming comes up people seem to generally regard the games of this era aging far worse then the earlier 2d generations of games. I don't think anyone would deny this was generallyba pretty good time for video games with a number of classic games released on every platform from the period but it feels like people generally look at the early 3d as being a limitation of the era, more so then any other era of gaming. Do you guys think early 3d has real merit as a timeless style of game or does a lot of it just look kind of ugly now?

To me I feel like fifth gen 3d is unique in that they still felt like they required a lot of imagination in how you can interpret what is happening in the game. With later 3d gaming everything id so clear you always knew what you were looking at and what is happening, it becomes hard to really leave anything up to the player's own imagination. That's not an inherent flaw, being able to tell what you're looking at is obviously great, but it's a charm I think only fifth gen 3d really has.

>>9644476
If we're talking about the mid to late 90s, as in the ps1/n64 era, then that's only really a console thing anon and most of it comes down to the controls more than anything else. Tons of 90s PC games hold up incredibly well today because you can fairly easily rebind the controls to something more modern or there's a fan patch available that lets you rebind them or whatever else. Meanwhile console games from around the same era were limited by the controller. Either the n64's bizarre mutant trident or the ps1 controller which was actually really good but had started off without analog sticks and most games, even towards the end of the ps1's life, were designed around the idea that you could still play it with a d-pad if you hadn't upgraded to a dualshock yet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
idk much about racers ne we liked them desu but RR4 pulled me in i guess aesthetically. heard the theme and gave it a try. the aesthetic is cool, the tracks aren’t crazy, but do have a nice feel, i especially love the three night time stages. the interfaces, menus, music, and character portraits all have this energetic yet still laidback feel, captures that cowboy bebop or ray crisis combo of badass action with lively jazz going on. the drifting is easy and intuitive, i like how especially as a beginner you can catch on quickly, however the levels get more punishing of your mistakes. just as gilbert says by the end you’ll be trying to run the perfect race. speaking of gilbert one thing that really set R4 apart from every other racing game for me were the stories they’re nothing too deep, but they’re fun, simple, and the two middle ones, ESPECIALLY the PRC story do enough to grip you just enough to add a story motivation to the fun gameplay. that’s what captured me, but lll expose myself and say i’m a complete outsider. hydro thunder, NFS: HP, GT II, Wipeout, TOCA, i don’t play any of those shits, so maybe R4 is just the most accessible in that way. oh and most of the OST kicks ass

TLDR: cool ass menus, music, simple but serviceable characters, easy to learn, somewhat difficult to master gameplay, but im less than a noob to racers, so take it with a grain of salt.

>>9635371
>It’s the only rpg I play without fast forward. Filtered

are you trolling? Possibly my biggest problem with Cross, even bigger than the total shitshow exposition dumps at the end of the game, is that Cross has extremely long combat animations and the intro/outro to combat is long even by JRPG standards, and enemies flat out interrupt your turn and do long animations of their own, and you can't even spend those animations menuing like you can in the original game (benefit of ATB!). Just comparing sequences in Trigger and Cross where you have to kill packs of enemies, the reptite tower is totally painless because it takes Crono half a second to draw his sword and transition into combat, and it takes two seconds to mash through text boxes at the end of combat, meaning that when you fight multiple packs of enemies it doesn't feel like your time is wasted and its all one big connected action sequence. Meanwhile, killing all the enemies is Gaea's Navel and ESPECIALLY clearing Marbule is like pulling fucking teeth, i can't believe you could honestly play those sections without thinking that they needed to rethink how they present the combat system. It's a totally amateur approach that's synonymous with so many other lame jrpgs, especially when contrasted with its six year old predecessor that already solved the problem.

>Masato Kato was the most important writer in Chrono trigger.
That's a filthy lie. Yuji Horii was the main writer of Chrono Trigger. Kato was one of the many writers assigned to flesh out the various time periods. Kato was assigned to Zeal and you can see his influence in all the dream stuff that goes nowhere and has no relevance to the main plot. But he was always only allowed to follow Horii's outline.

As a side note, Kato hated time travel and when he was brought into the staff to help in the middle of development his first suggestion was to cut out time travel entirely from the story. But of course, he wasn't actually in charge and was overruled in his most egregious stupidity.

>Kato did not want this to be a time travel story. He was outvoted in an early meeting.

>Kato fleshed out Zeal, but not the other time eras.

It's a similar process to comparing the SW OT to the prequels to understand what Luccas was responsible for (worldbuilding, grand scenery, creative aliens, sense of wonder, heroic story) and what he wasn't (dialogue, characters, the story making sense.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What does it tell us about Kato? The entire city of dreamers fits with the pseudophilosophical meandering he's fond of, and is also entirely disconnected from the rest of the game. I'm sure this was entirely his. He has said that he came up with the plot of Zeal, but we have to remember that he did not think of Crono's death, so he can't have written everything about Zeal. He definitely had a hand in Schala's story, but he can't have written everything about her either or he wouldn't have felt the need to retcon so much about her in Cross (even her hair is different!) and he definitely would not have written her brother out of the sequel when he was so central to her.

For other sections that you seem to have attributed to Kato, I'm also confident in saying that he did NOT write Fiona's forest and the camp scene (goes against Cross's message of "humans bad for environment" and the campfire scene is contradicted in Cross), he did not write anything about prehistory (Cross even says that humans did not exist before Lavos arrived, retconning Ayla into a neanderthal), etc, he did not write any of the happy endings (he hated happy endings and retconned them into tragedies with his sequel) and he did not write any of the whimsical scenes of Trigger (too many to list).

Now, you may come and say that this means nothing, we can't actually compare the writing like that and he's responsible for more than I give him credit for, but then we need the answer to a simple question: If Kato wrote all that, why the hell did he feel the need to retcon, contradict or alter so much of it in the sequel? If Kato really is responsible for most of Trigger, as crossfags keep asserting, why the hell are the two games NOT mostly similar in theme, tone, or most of anything, really? Is your answer going to be that the games are actually very similar and the audience is just too dumb to understand Kato's genius, as I have heard in the past?

>LA is a superior game to LttP in every way.
Arguably true. I love LTTP a lot, but I think my favorite is the Oracle games, because they're like LA but far more vast and comparatively more challenging. Played them for the first time a year or two back when recovering from surgery, and fuck me, they were so much better than I ever expected.

>Wario Land is just a hard game to play these days. I don't mean like it's difficult or bad or anything, but it's like playing a game for babies. There's no challenge and even the secrets are super obvious.
Heh, well, it's not particularly hard, no, (though I'm pretty bad at most platformers) but I find the game irresistibly charming for its overall design and character. I love Wario as the anti-Mario, greedy, crude, violent, two-faced, he's really just in with whatever he does for making money so he can live in great comfort, he's not noble at all and he's not ashamed of that.

The first Wario Land gets it so well, fucking with Mario didn't really pan out, but hey, what if he besieged that pirate den island to then rob those fuckers for every penny and pretty trinket they've got? They're crooks, he can't get in trouble with Mario for that, right? This makes it yet better that Wario Land 2 starts with said pirates breaking into his castle when he's sleeping to rob him of the money he robbed from them (also flooding his basement), and thus begins his quest of getting back his stolen-stolen shit.
Wario being this absolute lout preoccupied with money makes him a lot more fun and interesting to me than Mario, and they figure that out even with the gameplay itself, Wario being less about jumping on top of enemies, and instead bumping them over to pick up and throw them, or giving them a running/jet assisted tackle sending them flying out the level. Optionally groundpounding them flat with his big ass, which slams down with such force that the earth quakes for a split second.

Plenty of reasons to play DX

- colours that look good for the most part (the counter example provided above isn't enough to dismiss all the other parts of the game that look good)
- extra dungeon with good fights (was it 2 or even 3 bosses?) and good puzzles. Entirely made of new graphics and new enemies, so it's not just lazy rehash shitty dungeon like so many ports have (Final Fantasy GBA games, Chrono Trigger on DS, etc)
- Extra tunic if you want them. Note that you can very well ignore them: play through the entire colour dungeon, beat the final boss, and exit through the front door without picking up either tunic.
- Photograph quests that adds new cutscenes that in some cases help build identity for characters that lacked it, and the photo graphics are comical and full of soul

Meanwhile all the anti-DX have against the game are:
- a choke full of stuff that DX itself didn't start and which is also true found in this or that version of the original.
- "it looks bad", usually trying to "prove" it by focusing on minor details nobody had noticed when playing like >>9637205. And even if you don't like the colours, guess the fuck what, you can play DX in black&white. So that doesn't hold either.

Link's Awakening was my first Zelda, I had one of the non-DX European version. After I discovered DX there was no reason to come back to it.

I have no idea why the internet is so intent on shitting on DX. Usually people will pull up with a tons of shit for a bit "extra content" of dubious quality (again, those ports of FF/CT I mentionned). Here you have extra content that's actually original, true to the game and well designed; and instead people will go through lengths to use unfair arguments against the game.

In fact, the extra dungeon is designed in such a way that a first time player is likely to miss it completly without outside knowledge, yet someone who has already played the non-DX version or someone who's already played the game will pay attention to it
>what's up with this book? I don't remember this from the original game..
or
>what's up with this book? I completely missed it on my first play

Whereas someone playing it the first time is likely to see the book at the start of the game and forget about its existence.
It was made this way specifically to offer a bonus for replays and to offer a different experience than the first time with the tunics as a reward if you figure it all out.

So the only way you "ruin your first playthrough" is if you're looking up a guide; and someone who did manage to figure out how to get to the dungeon and beat it as soon as it's available, on his own, isn't likely to consider the reward "ruining the game".

>>9641480
I find there are a great deal of people, including myself on occasion, who find certain things in games that are permanent to be extremely irritating. For me it's usually when I just want to be able to revisit a certain element without replaying the entire game, ie. seeing funny dialog from an in-game event a second time, but it's halfway into a long game that doesn't offer multiple save files. It generally just boils down to "I don't want to have this happen to me so I will avoid it even if it is more work" or "I don't want to have to play half the game again just for this one thing".

I've also seen people get irritated that games stop them from doing 100% of possible tasks and situations in a single playthrough, which is ironic given those games are usually designed to let you do have a reason to replay the game. I think it's something for people who like the game enough to play it once but not enough to want to replay it. The prospect of not being able to see everything just drives them up a wall. That said, those people are likely also very self-deprecating completionistswho put way too much pressure on themselves to finish games and to act like beating a game is another checkbox on a grocery list. Kind of like backlog obsessors, they drive their play habits not by want of fun but by guilt of not having finished a game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
SRPG is a Japanese abbreviation (of English words), "Simulation RPG" -- it came about because the term "war simulation" was the genre term for war games in Japan, and for whatever reason the word "simulation" rather than "war" came to be used to abbreviate the genre. Then when they added named characters & experience points to it they called that a "Simulation RPG"

TRPG is an English abbreviation, "Tactical RPG" It came about because people thought SRPG stood for "Strategy RPG" and they didn't like that that didn't match the content of the games, which are about tactics. Either that or because Tactics Ogre and Final Fantasy Tactics were popular.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'd like to use a new term that applies to almost all FE games.

Puzzle Tactics game.

It's a "tactics" game where the emphasis is on "solving" a level by doing a very precise and rigid set of moves with very little room for improv.
To that end FE games tend to have side-objectives that emphasize rushing towards a part of the map where some unit is doing something on a "timer" so you have to immediately move a certain way with certain units to reach it. Also the weapon triangle makes it so very specific units can defeat other ones which are statically placed so you have to send a certain unit a certain way to accomplish that. Also the weapon triangle makes it so using a wrong unit can have them wiped out in even one attack, which reinforces the "correct" way of doing things and minimizes improv.

Games that would fit in this sub-genre are also Advanced Wars and (not retro) Into the Breach.

An example of a non-puzzle tactics game is Tactics Ogre, where you have more control over your party customization and loadout and the enemies can be defeated in a more fluid, back-and-forth way. Certain maps where you recruit special units are tailored mostly towards rushing them a specific way, but these are generally rare and special cases. In general you can flop around, lose some units, recover, and legitimately use "tactics" to win.
UFO and XCOM are also "true" tactics games.

My point is that the game forces you into a very narrow "problem-solving" approach both in map layout, units given and so on... certain units are specifically designated to defeat certain opponents and you almost always have to use them that way.

In "true" tactics games like XCOM or Tactics Ogre you are given a far more broad approach in dealing with situations tactically, rather than treating levels/battles as problems to solve a very specific way.

posts.sub: This does not hold up at all
posts.com:
-You just hack and slash and spam overpowered special attacks.
-QTEs, literally the exact type the gaming community ubiquitously agreed on being rubbish but somehow doesn't mind in these games.
-Button mashing you have to do all the time to open things or to get health from enemies, which couldn't be more annoying and user-unfriendly.

-Occasional platforming segments that are as clunky as they are unfitting and tacked-on with a rather detrimental time-to-solve-in-your-head/time-to-actually-execute ratio
-The much lauded 2 literally starts with a QTE like in a party game:
https://youtu.be/QAjwSDecOrU?t=464

What also doesn't help is that they tried very hard to make Kratos the most unlikeable protagonist of all time. Even ignorign the bald-angry-guy stuff, it's like they were catering to a 12-year-old who just discovered Shadow the Hedgehog GMVs and just likes things that are edgy for the sake of being edgy, like in the cutscene where Kratos doesn't care enough to save a random person's life he could easily save but...cares enough to let him know how little he cares:
https://youtu.be/Lbj5C-Sw2_A?t=1307

Why would you write such a terrible character? I have no idea why I should care about his fate. Not to mention that it intricately pokes holes into the whole story and writing: The biggest piece-of-garbage asshole continues being caught off-guard by people backstabbing him? Alright

Then there is the presentation which you could say was the reason this series took off. Honestly, though, it's not that great. There is a lot of trickery going on with static camera angles and the weird flat visuals throughout the entire game that look like they forgot to add polygons. Almost as shallow as the gameplay

>>9641226
I like Seymour for what he is.
He's certainly not a good enough character to be the main antagonist, but he's a great recurring villain.
It's interesting how he's thinking and acting on an entirely different scale than every other character in the game.
I also like that you can use a turn to call him a piece of shit mid-battle. That's fucking great, every Final Fantasy game should do that.

I never felt that the characters were written too irrationally.
Auron has his own plan, Tidus doesn't know what's going on, Rikku is trying her best, and everyone else has a martyr complex the size of Arizona.
There are a few scenes that are played for melodrama but nothing was a dealbreaker for me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9638939
>>9643125
>Random Encounters
I don't know why this is such a big deal to people.
Does seeing the enemy on the map and bumping into them before combat really just light your soul on fire? I've never cared that much.
If you hate them, there's a way to earn the ability to turn off random encounters in game. Is that still not enough for you?
>Bad writing
The Japanese version has very solid writing.
I haven't seen the English version in a while but from my memory it isn't particularly worse than other JRPG translations.
>Unskippable cutscenes
There are a few boss fights in this game that use Petrify and Death status effects, and unless you keep anti-stone anti-death equips on 100% of the time there's a good chance you'll have to go through them more than once.
Other than that I can't think of any situation you would want to skip a cutscene in this game.
>Save points
It's 2023. If this is a dealbreaker for you, use save states.
>Bad tutorials
By this I'm assuming you're talking about the in battle tutorials where the characters give advice to each other?
Those end in Mi'ihen and I thought they were cute. In total, they're like, two minutes of the game, max.
>Awful character design
I think Yuna, Rikku, and Lulu have awesome character designs, as do all the summons.
Auron and Kimahri look pretty cool too imo.
Tidus and Wakka are fashion rejects, but in a kind of lovable way that makes sense for their characters.
>Weird voices
I can only recommend you play the Japanese version or one of the many undubs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9643384
>Other than that I can't think of any situation you would want to skip a cutscene in this game.
Not him, but I remember restarting a few times to win that first blitzball match and the unskippable intro cutscene was annoying. Besides that, why would you want to skip cutscenes in a story-driven RPG?
I don't mind it as a QoL improvement though, especially if it comes with a pause function. Some games just slap skip on the start button without telling you so, when it acts as pause everywhere else in the game and that's stupid and counter-intuitive. A perfect way to do this is to have the start button pause the cutscene and then offer you an option to skip or resume it, like in MGS4 or the Yakuza series, for example. That should really be a standard for all games. Too bad they didn't include it in the remaster.
>I can only recommend you play the Japanese version or one of the many undubs.
Seconded. I can't bear the English dub in this game, it ruins it for me. The original voices are MUCH better. Again, I wish the remaster let you change the language without resorting to mods and file-swapping (which makes it exclusive to the PC version, too).
In general, FF dubs had a rough start in English, but every installment starting from XII onwards had a great dub. Sure, there are a few exceptions like Vanille sounding outright retarded in XIII, but for most of the time they're pretty good, even if I prefer Japanese voices overall (save for XII, the EN dub is phenomenal and I prefer it over JP).
On that note, which dub is supposed to be the main one for XVI? I feel like the English voices are going to be really strong this time, but I'll probably play the game more than once and taste both anyway.

While it is a little known fact that a good half of the enemies in Dragon Warrior 2 hand out more exp/gold than their counterparts in Dragon Quest 2, what nobody knowns (and which isn't documented yet) is that the stats of all enemies were also rebalanced for the western version.

Every enemy in Dragon Warrior 2 is easier. Whether that is attack, def or agility, values, and I think in some cases even HP and probability to use this or that move (I'd have to check back to make sure of that). In most cases there are subtle changes to most values.

So when you see people who have played Dragon *Warrior* 2 and hear them cry about
>waaah this game is too hard! I mean the end game is hard how does that make sense??!! Look even the devs said it was too hard!
They have absolutely no right to use the dev stuff as an excuse because they were already playing a version in which the difficulty had been adressed to begin with.

Dilate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9633787
While it is a technical possibility to get ambushed and OHKO'd from a death spell in the late game, it is very unlikely to happen when you reached the level gap. The higher your level, the less likely you will be to get ambushed, and the less likely death spells will be likely to hit.

>>9633749
>specially the sun one which is found on a specific tile on a southeastern shrine.

There is an NPC that tells you exactly where the shard is. That and you get the flute to help you locate the shards.That and the shrine is likely to be a place you visit when you use the warps.

As long as you pay attention and take notes when NPCs say things, you shouldn't have too much trouble.
Personally I love this stuff in the game, these adventure game mechanics are exactly what makes the game feel organic and alive, rather than having a game-y world with a tired "area is composed of one town, one dungeon, complete that and you're allowed to go the next area and repeat" routine.
In DQ2 towns work as hubs you come back to
in between several quests, and their inhabitants often provide clues that will be needed for things much later on; that and there is often a reason to come back to X or Y location later on. This makes the world feel alive and enhances the feel of adventure, something many other RPGs (DQ sequels included) fail at because they want to cater to the part of the audiance that just wanted to be hand holded through an adventure game.

>>9643348
The source is me checking the game code coupled with existing dissassembly and documentation to help (though I don't trust the dissassembly too much because external docs that come with it talk about things which aren't in the game at all, must be a romhack or something)

Example, Big Slug data in the Japanese version
08 00 03 01 04 0B 06 00 07 00 00 00 00 00

Big Slug data in the US version
08 00 03 02 03 09 06 00 07 00 00 00 00 00

So on top of the exp given being changed from 01 to 02 (already a known thing easily checked by playing or checking guides), the attack value was changed from 0B to 09, losing 2 points.

Pretty much every enemy has changes like that, some more substantial than that too.

I'll document it all one of these days, but it takes time; and I intend to check up on other things too like probability for enemies to use this or that spell or to drop items etc

>>9643352
>know more than the devs

The "we didn't have time to properly test and balance the game" excuse was from a Japanese interview, thus talking about the Japanese version. One should also take into account that they spent one month and a half (november/december 1986) doing nothing but debugging and balancing the game. That's a lot of time. The game was delayed for that purpose specifically.
The fact is, making RPGs hard and require grinding was a norm then, which as a whole gradually decreased with time (and the US version is from 1990, thus the adjustements)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9636792
>if you rewind before you got hit.. did you really learn how to dodge that attack?
Yes, because if you don't learn how to dodge it then you'll just get hit again and become stuck in a rewind loop until you learn how to not get hit. It's actually a much faster way to learn.

Without rewind, you either take the hit without dying and keep moving forward having learned little-to-nothing until next time or you die and restart the entire stage and have to replay until you get to the part where you died and try not to die.

With rewind, you get hit and then immediately rewind so you can analyze what hit you and why, then keep rewinding until you know exactly how to avoid it. It's the same practice loop as above, just done immediately instead of spread out over a long period of time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9638054
The post I originally replied to literally says:
>i eventually learn to beat it because i'm picking up on stuff and applying learned muscle memory to this difficult situation.
Which is all much more quickly learned through immediate repetition. It's the difference between improving your free throw in basketball by throwing 100 free throws each day and improving your free throw by playing an entire game of basketball each day. One gives you distinctly fewer repetitions of what you're trying to improve. You need to practice the whole game, too, obviously, but these individual fundamental skills are best improved through maximum repetition. If you want to master dodging a specific boss's attack then the best thing you can do is rewind repeatedly until you've got all the cues and timings down. Practicing the game as a whole is a separate thing with a different practice method.

>>9640856
Is it mental gymnastics to say that throwing 100 free-throws in a row is better free-throw practice than playing an entire game of basketball? The latter will take significantly more time but offer significantly fewer chances for a free-throw. If you want to practice beating one specific section of a game, it's better and faster practice to repeat that section over and over than to restart the entire game each time.

To use a more video game oriented analogy, competitive fighting game players go into practice mode and repeatedly practice inputs for the same move or combo repeatedly for long stretches of time. That way when the pressure is on during a real game they're less likely to drop their inputs. Playing a whole match is also practice, but if you want to practice one move the best thing to do is just repeat it over and over, same goes for rewinding a single segment repeatedly until you have it down.

They very deliberately invoked that kind of vibe. The original AOF was one of the few fighting games of the time that wasn't about a bunch of people joining a fighting tournament, instead it was about two bros beating people up in shady parts of town looking for a kidnapped girl, a plot far more common in beat'em ups. I almost wish AOF had been a beat'em up, it would have been a great one for sure and wouldn't have suffered all the direct comparisons to SF2 that caused a lot of people to look down on it. And the characters could still have been used in KOF anyway.

Nah all those were pretty lame. It's such a shame too because SNK obviously put a lot of effort into AOF3, it's quite possibly the prettiest game on the Neo Geo. The sprites are huge and the rotoscoped animations are fluid as fuck, some stage have some fancy light and shadow effects, the gameplay was vastly improved from the previous games with a really satisfying combo system. But for some reason they chose to put all of that into a side story with a bunch of randos and the incredible latino Hulk for a boss instead of following up on the plot threads laid down in the previous game which had specifically namedropped Jeff Bogard to set up his confrontation with Geese. That's what AOF3 should have been about.

I dont remember where I heard this but one thing that might’ve stopped AOF3 from taking off is that knockdowns took way to long to recover from, which seems minor until you’re a hundred rounds in and getting fed up with it. I know about the otg hits you can do but everyone always stays down for like five seconds and it breaks the flow of things.

This mostly only applies to the autistic tourney player side of fighting games, since they’re the ones who are playing CONSTANTLY so a little thing that can add up like this becomes a bigger deal.

As a more casual player I liked AoF3 quite a lot. Went through everyone’s story mode last year and had a very fun time. Really enjoyable single player quest for a fighting game.

I really liked the single player stuff for all the AoFs and FFs actually. KoF sort of went too far with the ancient gods and family bloodline and clone army nonsense, but the world of FF/AoF/Garou was a cool one I wanted to see more of. I really like that corny 80s/90s streetbrawler vibe they had.

It's a sad reality that the games that get remade...
- are already so good they are perfectly playable as they were
- are so well known they won't benefit from the extra exposure the remake provides
- are so beloved any minor changes will piss fans off
- are so historically important people will want to play the classic version anyway

This thread is instead for those games where a remake could be a game changer that will never happen, those games you see have something special and are full of unique potential but for one reason or another are not as good as they deserved to be. Post and discuss them

A JSRF remake or rerelease will never happen because the music rights are a nightmare. Most of the soundtrack (I believe all of the non-Naganuma tracks) was owned by a record label that went bust shortly after the game came out, and the rights went everywhere. posts.name: Anonymous

>>9642142
it's kind of like translating Japanese to English. Shit is like a one to many situation all of the time simply because Japanese doesn't have a lot of ways to skin a cat (especially when compared to the nightmare gobblrfuck that is English) and so you could probably take a script in Japanese, give it to 5 different translators, and get 5 different translations, depending on all manner of things. Likewise, from a single blurry texture you could get 5 different interpretations by artists.

It's the problem of having to define one answer to an open question. It's like when gunpei yokoi defended using a black and white screen on the game boy. He said that if you draw two circles on top of each other on a whiteboard and say "it's a snowman" then people will fill the gaps in their mind of what the snowman looks like. Ask one artist to draw a detailed snowman to be "the" snowman in this, and someone observing it will say that it's not what they had imagined.

This is why movie adaptations of books can often seem off vs .the originals, because you read them and have an idea of what the characters look and sound like, all for it to be torn up when you see the Hollywood version where one team of (hopefully) interested people decided what every character and element would look like and would sound like and forced it upon everyone else.
It's also why Bill Watterson fought tooth and nail against merchandise for Calvin and Hobbes; He never wanted to get to the point of making a movie or tv show and having to decide what Hobbes' voice sounded like. That was for the reader to decide as they enjoyed the comic for themselves.

tl;dr a remake can basically never change graphics in any way without potentially alienating someone because there are too many ways to take something vague and turn it into something specific and inevitably, someone will like their own interpretation of it better.

The robots in megaman classic do have self-awareness and emotions, but what separates them from Reploids is the fact that they cannot act upon what they perceive and feel unless programmed to. Wily has to modify them into acting erratically and dangerously.
As for Rock in MM7, it could be that years of experience saving people and making choices, as well as continuous upgrades from Dr. Light eventually resulted in Rock developing a primitive form of agency that ALMOST emerged when he was about to shoot Wily (regardless of localization text because it sure looked like he was about to blast the old man's face right off). Light noticed this and thus began working on X. Is it canon? No, but it makes sense. Even our current-year primitive AI experiments eventually develops its own ideas that skirt the limits of what it's allowed to do, it's not far fetched.

>>9640490
>This is false, why do people keep saying that

The Sega Saturn had 1046 games:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Sega_Saturn_games

And of them, 82 supported saving directly to the memory card:
https://segaretro.org/Saturn_Backup_Memory#Compatibility

Many popular exclusives like NiGHTS, Astal, Burning Rangers, Bulk Slash, Clockwork Knight, Scud, and all of the Panzer Dragoon games did not support the feature.

>>9640526
>Action Replay / Gameshark cannot do this. It can only back-up memory.

Also this. The older 2/3/4-in-1 cards from the 90s had additional storage, but you could only move/copy saves to them from their own Action Replay-like menu, when a game was booted they just functioned like a 4MB RAM expansion, not as a memory card. The more recent ones you get today can function as a real memory card... for those 82 games.

>>9640775
>These kinda batteries lasted for decades in cartridges, why do they drain so fast in the Saturn?
Probably the mess of hardware the system is and the fact that the battery powers both the SRAM and the RTC.

How is that good? Most save or clock batteries last around 20 years, at worst 10.

NTA but do you have any recommendations from personal experience? Because everybody cares about and documents the converters the other way around, but never the HDMI *to* composite ones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9641885
I have been milling about looking at various converters, the only good ones tend be from smaller hobbyist shops that are annoying to acquire easily.

Say you serious and are building a media PC dedicated for a CRT i think the best way to go about it is start with an older AMD GPU(15 bucks on ebay) that has DVI-I or VGA outputs then to converter then to your TV. The reason to use an older AMD GPU is because theres a driver on windows that will do resolution switching between 240p and 480i modes and all sorts of various CRT related settings that makes things work more authentically. This is an almost essential feature when dealing with an an older retro emulator machine because sprites start looking blurry without the proper 240p scanlines

HDMI does not play nicely with CRT from various CRT groups ive read, i think its because theres a floor of how low of a resolution HDMI can go down to which fucks with pixel scaling or some shit. Its just something to avoid whenever possible.

>How does Arcade games on a CRT work?
Perfectly fine.
> is there any limitations on what you can do on a consumer CRT in terms of arcade resolutions?
If it is a 24hz or 31khz arcade game then you will need a CRT that supports those resolutions. Something like a multisync monitor from NEC or Mitsubishi. 31hz is widely supported on basically any PC CRT monitor since it is similar to 640x480 vga.
>Can you even rotate consumer CRTs to play TATE without damaging them?
Yes, no problems.

>>9645010
LCD and OLEDs do not usually have a glass screen. So there would not be "glass in front of glass". There would be only one layer of glass.
And yes, it would help in a number of ways including adding contrast to the image and diffusing the light produced by it in a way that could be potentially flattering. Have you never seen an arcade monitor under smoked (not tinted) glass? Have you ever heard of the term micro-contrast?

But yes, aesthetics are the main goal here. To mask the edges of the 16:9 screen in a more sophisticated way. To have something that looks nice in a game room. These could be very large sizes, you know. Much easier to work with this than a 40" or larger CRT.
Using an OLED the image quality would be outstanding.
>burn-in
Please. We can be better than that with the baitposting and FUDing about that.
We all know that it is not a real issue for anyone who plays a good variety of games for a reasonable number of hours per day. Even playing hundreds of hours of the same game isn't going to have an effect on the new generations of the tech and if you're so worried you can just buy an LCD. Or maybe microLED one of these days.

posts.com: When Iga got the English recordings for the SotN localization back, he found that Alucard's original reaction to Death stealing his equipment was inappropriate. Originally, Alucard was to say "No!" in response. However, the English voice actor got the tone completely wrong, sounding to Iga like "Noooo, don't take my stuff!" So, he went to Konami's sound department and asked for a stock sound they could use instead. The "What?!" present in the final version is the result.

posts.sub: Explaining digital vs analog inputs for games w/ digital controls
posts.com: How do I explain to my zoomer roommate, in the easiest-to-understand way possible, that using an analog stick to play a game that uses 8-direction digital control is not optimal? Don't get me wrong; how he plays his own games is none of my business. But he's convinced that an analog stick is the best choice for shmups, 2D platformers, and fighting games, and when he sees me make a mistake in one of these games, he often tells me that I'm putting myself at a disadvantage by using the d-pad, and that I'd have an easier time if I used the analog stick instead. He even suggests using an analog stick for NES games. He's pretty smug about it, despite being so wrong, and I'm tired of hearing it. But I'm bad at giving explanations. While we at /vr/ can argue forever about which digital input is best, surely we all agree that analog isn't ideal, right? I don't know how to explain to him WHY digital inputs like a d-pad are the better option, in a way that he can understand. How should I go about explaining this to him? Preferably in a way that doesn't come across as elitist or condescending.

posts.com: Make an agreement with him where you'll play with analog and he'll play with d-pad.

An analogue stick cannot magically make a digital game have analogue controls, but it can make using those digital controls easier to use. Easy example is how doing diagonals on d-pad can be hell on your thumb sometimes, but is effortless on analogue stick.

Obviously not all analogue sticks are created equal, some have shit deadzones that make rapid back and forth motions hard, some shoot past neutral enough to misinput when you let go, etc...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In a game designed for digital, it only accounts for 8 directions: up, down, left, right, and all 4 diagonals.
In a game truly designed for analog, there are many more small variations of those directions. So by using analog for a digital game, you lose precision as pushing the stick slightly to the upper left or all the way to the upper left leads to the same result.

Also personally I find that with a joystick you lose time as well. Going from the top left diagonal to the bottom right diagonal takes me a split second longer with a stick than with a d-pad.

But I don't know, it's very much possible that a zoom zoom has an easier time with analog still because that's all he's known all his life and he doesn't even know how to properly position his thumb on a dpad or something. I don't know how zoom zooms work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9645945
>you lose precision as pushing the stick slightly to the upper left or all the way to the upper left leads to the same result.

That's not directly harmful though. You get extra choices of what exact directional signals you'll send up the controller wire, yeah, but an ideal cyborg-person could discard all but exactly nine relevant choices and then just use those and only those, if having extra choices is the only difference between the two input devices. The extra choices are fine in themselves.

The problem is the other differences. I think the biggest one is probably the travel distance, as you say. On a d-pad, if I need to move my Tetris Attack cursor four spaces to the right or if I'm in any of the many games that let you tap right twice to run and I want to run, then I'll just gently and briskly tap on the right button a few times, because it's a button. It's very simple and natural and fast. With a stick, I need to rock my thumb weirdly, so that the stick dances across the intangible boundary between the right-direction zone and the central dead zone. If I go too far I'm wasting time and I might even fail to get my character to run. If I don't go far enough then I might miss the boundary and wiggle uselessly on one side of it, sacrificing one or more button presses entirely. It's crap, and only a fool like OP's roommate would prefer it.

>>9645608
>Easy example is how doing diagonals on d-pad can be hell on your thumb sometimes,

After thirty years of using d-pads I still haven't ever experienced whatever you're talking about. Maybe you and I touch the d-pad with different parts of our thumbs?

>>9643979
I love it. I always have.

You must play it two player with someone who likes using the vehicle you don't use. Lot's of teamwork involved and it's very hard. Tons of weapon power ups, and deplete-able sub-weapons.

Lots of enemies and they come in fast. Hardly any slowdown. Good soundtrack, gritty 80s arcade graphics transport you back into a futuristic cold-war era.

Helicopter can dodge ground enemies, tank can dodge flying enemies, both can't dodge their shots. Helicopter can move all over fast, but can only shoot straight. Tank moves slower, and has to dodge/jump ground obstacles, but can fire in diagonal front directions.

No other game is quite like it, certainly on the SNES. It's been getting more popular, as it should. It is definitely one of the best co-op SHMUPs.

posts.com: There's a weird debate about this game ongoing for the last twenty years and people just sort of talk past each other about it. People like it because it's calm and contemplative, and sort of like the gaming equivalent of listening to ambient music. It's atmospheric and the simplicity of the gameplay and flawed controls/extremely minimal HUD is questionably a feature rather than a defect. I don't really care much about the technicals, I just like it because i like wandering, and the expanse of the game gives the sense of a believable but foreign world--like a waking dream. If you find the controls irritating to the degree that it makes you question why people like this, that makes sense to me too. It's just a matter of preference.

I think it's actually a good puzzle game too, where the solution to each colossus is mostly logical so you don't need a guide, but offers a decent challenge at the same time. I like the adrenaline of climbing and managing the grip meter too.
>the expanse of the game gives the sense of a believable but foreign world--like a waking dream.
I agree completely and the scale gave this both surreal and very real sense of loneliness. When you'd ridden around for a long time and suddenly stumbled across something new you felt like you'd actually discovered something yourself, compared to games where you're given something new every five seconds. It's not for everyone though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm gonna hypothesise Soulsbourne games wouldn't exist without SOTC.

It's like all FromSoft did was add enemies between bosses and some RPG shit in, and there you have it, Dark Souls. Everything else, the vague mysterious abstract plot, the gameplay that essentially boils down to boss rush with sequences of exploration in between, overall weeb-but-western melting pot art direction, etc is strongly paralleled.

Only reason I don't really like either of those series is because I never liked boss fights, boss fights are always my least favourite part of any game; but other than that I respect what they did. SotC deserves respect as a pioneer of a lot of modern gaming trends, but like all pioneering games it looks weaker in retrospect.

>>9638734
>>9641319
The only similarities I can see are that they're fantasy games with mysterious plots and depict the ruins of a Western civilisation with a kind of alien feel to it. King's Field IV came out first and already had a weird, bleak, interconnected fantasy setting with strange and depressed NPCs scattered around that all had lines that would fit seamlessly into any Dark Souls game.

The nature of the mystery elements is also pretty different, in SotC things are mysterious because you're told almost nothing about the setting, whereas Souls games have a ton of flavour text and dialogue containing cryptic references to figures and events you have no context for, almost begging you to try and connect the dots. In SotC you're hardly given any dots to connect.

Even then I think you could argue this mystery element wasn't quite as strong in Demon's Souls anyway and only really took off in Dark Souls. If you just want to say that SotC inspired them to switch to third-person, maybe, but in that case I'd argue SotC's contribution was pretty minor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9642406
>Was Capcom really that clever to prevent hackers from hacking the CPS2 hardware? I mean if that was the case, then hacking it isn't much of a chore anymore

Yes and no.

The idea of having the game's main data encrypted and put the encryption key on volatile memory powered by a battery that would wipe itself if tampered was pretty effective. Yeah, one could argue about how when the battery dies people would have to send the board to Capcom to get them to reload the key, but considering the battery lasts some 20 or so years that's hardly intentional planned obsolesce as the arcade cabinet itself is likely to be retired before that Nobody was expecting people to care about old games or that retro gaming would boom like it did.

And no in that the reason CPS2SHOCK was able to crack it in the early 00s was due to (if I remember correctly) an oversight Capcom left in from a CPS2 game they had converted to CPS1 hardware. I recall it was some older Street Fighter game, I guess they figured the revenue from arcades that could install the game in an old CPS1 cabinet was more profitable than keeping that old game out of bootlegger's hands. From what I remember they accidently left in an occasional call the game makes to the decryption hardware, which clued the team in that the CPS2 games didn't just decrypt the game once on boot but had to repeatedly confirm it for the board to keep decrypting the game or the system would stop decrypting. I am sure this would have eventually been figured out anyway (Especially since CPS3 was decrypted about 16 years ago) if they got the initial decryption done and then saw the game only works for a while, but it apparently gave them a target to know where to look and sped up the project. I remember when the site joked about renaming themselves to CPS3Shock right after they finally broke CPS2 wide open, since CPS2 took many years and people would have expected CPS3 if it ever happens to take an eternity...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9642914
The timing of all that was pretty funny too. I recall how Overclocked, back when that was a more a webcomic about emulation than known for a videogame remix community, had a poll asking people when they think CPS2 emulation would finally happen, as decrypting it had been seen as a holy grail for years. And the last option was something along the lines of "When Megaman learns to duck (I.E. never)"

.... and then around the time they did crack it Megaman X5 was also revealed.... the first game where Megaman could duck. (I remember there was an IGN video of it that was nothing but X just standing still and ducking for about a minute, with a joke title like "expert gameplay" or something like that.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Can I combine 2-3 hacks in the game? Or will it break? I want Simon's quest with normal advice, double hearts and no floor traps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622353
Sometimes it's possible, but it depends on how each patch was constructed. If one or more of them start moving data around that conflicts with the other patches it'll break. If there's no documentation about it then the only way to know for sure would be to try it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622353
Use Lunar IPS and make sure the "Create a log file" option is ticked, then check the log files and see if that no two hacks replaces the same addresses (offset + size)

in most cases if there are is no overlap then it should be compatible, unless as pointed out, one of the hacks moved data around and a change in another hack still thinks the data is in the original place.

How do you even do a check like that

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9625168
Programmer decides ROM read speed, but if it is too much for the cart it returns shit instead of the expected values.
So you enable the "fast" ROM read speed (the speed used by almost if not all commercial games), you read some data from ROM and if returned values are not what you expect you are using a piece of shit cart.

But after that, Sony was going to publish Night Trap and Sewer Shark for the Playstation CD add-on, Tom Zito was quoted as saying that he would have preferred to see the game get a release on the SNES-Playstation, because of the enhanced colour pallet. They was not happy with the muddy look of the Sega CD video.

>because it came with your Sega CD
It was basically a pack-in game for the entirety of the NA Sega CD. I had it with my Sega CD unit. But, it also came with the Sega 5-in-1 collection, Sonic CD and Ecco the Dolphin. I always had such a weird mixed reaction to Sewer Shark. Gameplay, was a standard FMV shooter, I don't think it's too bad. The game does try to mix up the gameplay with randomization of the tubes, and there are a few alt-FMV scenes when you play better or worse. The best thing is the film making aspect of the movie, and it was miniature tunnels, puppets and live action. I remember seeing one black and white behind the scenes photo from a long time ago. Could never find it again. I think it was a B&W scanned image. But it featured John Dykstra working on one of the model sewer pieces. Night Trap was pretty well documented during the filming process;. But Sewer Shark doesn't have much around it for behind the scenes material. The game has a 3 million dollar budget for a 1987 and 1988 filming.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9633459
Yeah. Gran Turismo isn't terrible impressive from a graphical standpoint, the biggest thing it had going was a more realistic physics engine than other console racing games from the era as well as a larger focus on "normal" cars alongside supercars. Kaz said that his inspiration for the first GT was basically "I want to drive my own car on the tv".

Gran Turismo 2 was where they started going apeshit and really pushing the PS1's hardware. They doubled the texture resolution on the cars to make sponsor logos on them more readable, for example. Backgrounds also got more detailed as well (the Seattle Circuit, surrounded by buildings and overpasses is a great example).

You're still limited to 6 cars on the track though (and the framerate tanks whenever more than a couple of them are on the screen), compared to something like >>9637450 that can support up to 40 cars at a time and still maintain 30fps.

Ultimately we'll never know what the Saturn was capable of, because Sega assfucked the launch and did a poor job of getting third party devs onboard, and even once they did their documentation was sparse and sometimes poorly translated, so they had to figure a lot of shit out on their own, which slowed progress.

There's a timeline out there somewhere where the Saturn got home ports of Virtua Fighter III and Daytona USA 2 and all of that, but sadly we'll never know what they looked like or how they performed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9638728
The Quake II port is pretty good, but it's not true Quake II. The amount of levels that were cut is extreme. It is pretty impressive graphically though (even though the "skyboxes" are just textureless goraud shaded walls in the windows kek). Having four player quad splitscreen multiplayer (and having it run at a decent framerate) is also pretty impressive, even if the multiplayer levels they created for it are smaller than my first apartment.

The Saturn got a port of Quake that if I remember right maintained every level except the secret ones, which were replaced with Saturn exclusive secret levels. It is significantly closer to the PC version of Quake than the PS1 version of Quake II is to the PC version of Quake II. Saturn Quake doesn't have multiplayer though, and the framerate chugs in some areas.

Still though, both are pretty impressive. People at the time said "The Playstation can't run Quake", "consoles aren't powerful enough" etc etc, and then Quake got ported to the Saturn and Quake II got ported to the Playstation, and now Unreal has been ported to the Saturn.

>>9643908
Virtua Fighter 2 looks better than Tekken 3, you are smoking crack. Tekken 3 does a significantly better job of blending the 3D fighting area with the 2D background image though, I will admit that. Virtua Fighter stages have an elevated platform over a flat plane (to facilitate Ring Outs), whereas Tekken fighters stand directly on the flat plane, which scrolls infinitely. The elevated platform makes the transition looks weird in comparison. The character models and textures (as well as the resolution) are where VF2 really excels when comparing the two.

You are absolutely right on your next point though - 3D platformers were a genre that didn't see a lot of releases on the Saturn - and also what it did get was mostly ports (this is a consequence of launching in an era where arcade games were incredibly popular). Had it lasted a full generation I'm sure we would have seen quite a few hitting the system once consumers stopped being satisfied with home console ports of quick playing arcade games. "Bringing the arcade into the home" was a big deal in the mid 90s (and we were finally starting to get to the point where home console ports could be near arcade perfect or even arcade perfect), but that interest changed as gamers started wanting more in-depth games (the kind of games that detractors would call "cinematic").

The Saturn had a lot of really excellent games, but it cannot and will not ever be able to compete with the PS1 in terms of the sheer quantity of games and the variety of geners available. It's better to focus on what the Saturn does and does well as opposed to focusing on games that never made it into the library at all.

Yes, the FOV in parts with pre rendered backgrounds is usually very big, with cameras far away from the characters.
This is why models are the way they are, there was no technical reason why they couldn't have used battle models outside of battles.

It is because they kept with the tradition of older FF games: all of them except 6 have closer FOV and more detailed characters in battle than they do in the world. They simply adapted that to 3D.

FF8 broke away from the tradition but as a result you have a much greater percentage of camera point of views that are closer to the characters, using scrolling backgrounds more when the characters move around.

>>9624513
This right here. I don't think it necessarily is a problem specific to random encounters either. It's a general problem with combat in story-centered JRPGs. What used to be the main part of the "story" in dungeon crawlers - i.e. you encounter an enemy that tries to kill you - is now turned into an obstacle that's in the way of the "real" story. By having so much linear scripted story it becomes more obvious that the random encounters aren't part of that story and it becomes just a chore you have to slog through.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9614145
if you look at the game files to see how it prioritizes alien missions it's actually quite cute and you can see how the game designers planned everything out. different alien species have different probabilities of doing a particular mission, and different regions get different mission probabilities.

>Europe gets a lot of infiltration missions because it's a major X-COM funding area
>but alien bases are rare there because aliens prefer to put those in more sparsely populated areas
>Southeast Asia gets a lot of abduction missions due to its huge population density
and so forth

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
in EU you should:

>put your starting base in Europe or North Africa which gives you the maximum # of funding countries covered
>start research on laser weapons immediately
>construct your base so the entrance lift is a choke point if the aliens raid it
>play sniper-spotter--don't shoot aliens with the guy who spotted them as he could get reaction shotted, use someone else
>never do nighttime crashed UFOs, there's no reason to not wait for morning

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>officers are morale boosters, not necessarily better soldiers--if they die in battle your squad will suffer a higher morale loss
>aliens will try to target your officers ahead of the grunts
>soldiers who get wounded and are out of action for longer than 15 days should be sacked and replaced by a new guy
>normally you will always want to use auto fire with ranged weapons
>ranged weapons in EU have damage roll of 0-200%, whereas TFTD uses 50-150%

>>9631206
>i'm not nearly as experienced with tftd so i can't really provide input on it
It's generally similar with the following important differences

>aliens will do shipping route attacks starting in April--these can have any alien race on them
>artifact sites will start appearing in July--these are always a Tasoth/Aquatoid mixed crew, and you cannot duck out of them due to a massive point penalty (-1000 points for failing to complete the mission, -3000 for ignoring it).
>the game will generate 12 artifact sites, one for each region of the globe
>colonies are always Tasoth/Aquatoid mixed crew in part 1 and Lobstermen in part 2, but the race that constructed the colony will send supply ships to it
>on lower difficulty settings you will get more port/island attacks and fewer shipping route/artifact sites
>in infiltration missions, none of the alien infiltration fleet lands--until you get advanced craft weapons you will not be able to shoot down most of the USOs
>the TFTD terror ship (Battleship) has more powerful weapons than the battleship (Dreadnought) so while you could easily shoot down a EU Terror Ship with two Interceptors+Avalanche missiles, it's extremely risky (but still possible) to attempt it in TFTD--since it also never lands, the only way to fight one is to shoot it down
>in base defense missions, up to 5 aliens will spawn inside your base
>the Barracuda has shorter range than Interceptor and can't fly as far before running out of fuel

>>9631206
>i don't recommend shooting down ufos in the first place, even if you're willing to accept getting less rewards from them, there's still a flat 20% chance of the game generating a free alien retaliation mission every single time you shoot a ufo down on superhuman (it's only 4% on beginner, but still) - most ufos generated by every single mission (retaliation ufos being the biggest exception) *will* land at least once while they're doing their thing

https://www.ufopaedia.org/index.php/MISSIONS.DAT

Most UFOs on most missions land except during retaliation. Small scouts only land during base construction or harvest missions (small scout #1 on harvest missions lands, #2 doesn't). The first terror ship on terror missions does not land either. Shooting a UFO down of course may spawn a retaliation mission, which is a 50% chance of occuring either in the region the shootdown was in or the region where the X-COM craft that shot it down is based. If a retaliation scout passes over your base, it may become revealed to the aliens, and the odds go up the more facilities the base has.

If you shoot down the Battleship attacking the base with an X-COM craft, or they don't find your base at all, the retaliation mission ends. If the aliens do attack and you beat them in a base defense mission, the retaliation mission is immediately restarted with a new Small Scout and they'll keep going for it until they fail to find your base or you shoot down the incoming Battleship. if you shoot it down with base defense weapons it produces the infamous bug with endlessly attacking Battleships.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9638543
If you're fighting a Battleship, the commander is on the bridge and will usually be carrying a Blaster Launcher, although early game it's more likely Heavy Plasma. In alien bases he always carries Heavy Plasma and will be in the central command room, though on Superhuman he'll spawn outside someplace due to lack of spawn nodes and it can be real hard to identify him without a Mind Probe.

Weapon loadouts for base defense missions are same as the Battleship, meaning the commander will likely have a Blaster Launcher, although he can spawn anywhere and again be very hard to identify without a Mind Probe. It's generally easiest to capture one from a Battleship as you can guarantee he'll always be on the bridge.

Note that you will also need a live alien leader to complete the research tree for Cydonia or Bust.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Battleships are easy to clear since you can just shoot up the central grav lift at aliens above and if you have Blaster Bombs, you can also fire them up there. Beware that aliens will fire Blaster Bombs down the grav lift at you as well. In the original games you could shoot a ranged weapon up the lifts to easily pick off aliens on the floor above you, but OXC makes it that the aliens can also shoot down the lifts at you which they used to not be able to do.

Also note the room I marked with an X. That room has a spawn node, and the large-sized terrorists (Reaper, Cyberdisc, and Sectopod) can spawn in there and get stuck and unable to leave. For the latter two you can be in for a nasty surprise when you go into that room and one of them is in there and facing you.
